My family has some kind of OEM-customers-complex, so all my computers are, unfortunately, manufactured. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-sad.gif[/img] At least all of them are mine. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img] Except one, now... well, back to the topic.

I still have my "first" computer near my desk, covered by dirt and trash (sometimes). I used to play Keen6 on it (using Win95 DOS mode) when I was just 9 years old, but a crash... er, *cough, cough*. It had a Pentium 166 MHz processor, 16 megs of RAM, and a 1.2 GB hard disk drive, with Windows 95 OSR2 (pre-)installed. After two years I added 16 MB more of RAM with no purpose at all. This computer was used by me until its screen exploded (15 inches CRT).

Then I bought my second computer, which is now *supposedly* used by my father, although the last time I saw it was covered with dust. It has a Celeron 1300 MHz, 256 MB of RAM, and a ~40 GB HDD. It came with a non-functional floppy disk drive, by the way. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-furious.gif[/img] After rediscovering Keen, I played it on that computer using WinXP+VDMSound, WinXP+DOSBox and finally,
Linux+DOSBox. I used it with a 15 inches CRT screen (at 800x600 at 85 Hz)

Now I have my third computer, and at the same time I bought it, I had to give my second computer to my father. It's a Pentium IV 2.93 GHz (I was very happy after realizing I could run DOS games faster with it and DOSBox) with 1 GB of RAM and a ~160 GB HDD. It has some fancy buttons & stuff, nothing interesting for me, but at least it works well for software-development, Keen modding, graphic editing & designing, and gaming purposes. I'm using it with a 17 inches LCD screen (at 1280x1024 px, wow! awesome graphics! [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-drool.gif[/img] )

The downside of this last computer is I can't run my old SUSE Linux 10.0 on it without a bunch of hardware incompatibility issues. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-sad.gif[/img] I hope the next time I can download huge CD images, propers drivers will be avaiable. I'm still trying to survive in the Windows (R) World (TM). [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-dead.gif[/img]

IMKO, DOSBox is the best thing since sliced bread. I use it for running Keen and other DOS games with this computer.

I'm surprised everyone's so keen on Vista - yes, let's all make our PCs run slower than they do now [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-wink.gif[/img]

It makes you wonder *why* your bare operating system needs a minimum of 512MB RAM to run...imagine how much useless stuff it will keep loaded all the time. Probably stuff like that commercial grade SQL server it will use to store your system settings.

That's an interesting point about putting a paging file on a USB 2.0 disk though (but it would slow things down too - USB2.0 is a lot slower than SATA or even PATA/IDE.) Kinda makes you think about how Linux has not only been able to do that for years, but it can also put its paging file on another PC over the network (great if you're running Linux on a computer with no disk drives, hard, floppy, USB or otherwise.) I don't think we'll ever see a version of Windows that flexible...

title: Re: Your Keen-o-matics
content:
Actually it's not a page file that goes on the drive -- it's a prefetch cache that Vista loads the pages it thinks you will need onto. For a sequential transfer the hard drive would be much faster, but the idea is that by exploiting the flash drive's fast random access times the interface can be more responsive. From a technical and security standpoint Vista has enough cool stuff in it to make any computer geek salivate. I have a hunch that it's going to be hard to tell any of this is going on behind the scenes. It seems like Microsoft tends to do great stuff in some areas, but do something else that makes all the effort a waste.

EDIT: Well, yes it's a page file, but it's a page file meant to store the pages you will need rather than those there was no space for in memory.________________

IMKO all the GUIs for Linux still need quite a bit of work to bring them up to Windows' quality, but the overall system stability is well worth the current limitations (the PC I'm using now has been running continuously without a restart for 87 days, 10 hours, 35 minutes as I write this - try doing that with a Windows box.)

Oh, and if you're after decent Bash-like scripting in Windows, it's there, it's just not obvious (look up cscript or wscript - you write your scripts in VB or JScript. It's actually surprisingly good. More like a mini-programming language than a scripting language, but still.)

title: Re: Your Keen-o-matics
content:
Dual monitor support: I don't know, but I think any distribution with XFree86 or X.org should support dual monitor set-ups. And that is almost all major distributions. Those things (XFree86/X.org) are the graphical environment core (like USER.EXE, GDI.EXE and VWIN32.VXD on Windows ME).

Suport for Pentium III: piece of cake, it comes ready.

Suport for Athlon 64: I don't know what kind of processor this is. It doesn't matter anyway, the Linux Kernel that comes precompiled with major distributions should work. Note that some distributions come precompiled for 32-bit processors. If you want to take advantage of 64-bit CPUs, and you aren't afraid of losing 16-bit application compatibility, then you've got to download a 64-bit edition of the distribution.

Windows-style interface: KDE. I love it.

Most of your programs to work...:

- Paint: The GIMP, KOffice.
- Notepad: Emacs, KDE KWrite/Kate, GNOME GEditor
- GIFAnimator: I don't know.
- To make Win32 apps run on Linux: WINE compatibility layer. (note, not all Win32 apps work very well with WINE, it's better to use their Linux counterparts).

I have Windows and Linux running together without any problems. It's safe as long as you partition the disk wisely during the distribution setup program.

I started with SUSE Linux 9.3. Then I continued with 10.0. I'm still using 10.0, but then I got a Knoppix DVD for free with a magazine, and I recommend it for you, excelent for those who need to step carefully into the GNU/Linux world.

I'm sure somebody knows what's the open-source alternative to GIFAnimator.

Remember, DOSBox runs on Linux too (and better than on Windows, I must say!).[hr][img]http://img136.imageshack.us/img136/983/vegetableswk2.gif[/img]

title: Re: Your Keen-o-matics
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]That can't be right - the idea of a swapfile is to store data from memory to make more room in the RAM - it doesn't make sense to build extra space for the swapfile onto the motherboard when you could just add more RAM and reduce the need for a swapfile completely.[hr][/quote]
There are several reasons -- first is that even now, most PCs ship with a limited amount of RAM. 2 gigabytes is a lot, and adding another two is around $200 to $400 U.S., right? Not to mention the size limits of the architecture. A two gigabyte stick of flash memory? $30. That's pretty compelling if you're looking to put some data in a place where you can get to it quickly. Also, don't forget that RAM needs to be powered all the time, meaning that you can't use it when hibernating. You have to write everything you think you'll need upon resume to the disk, then load it all back in. Now what if you had another couple of gigabytes that would just be there for you as soon as you resumed? Pretty handy. And don't forget that many people are using mobile systems. The more data you can have in ram or additional flash, the less you need to spin up the hard disk and kill your battery.

Also, don't forget that Vista does more than load what you need into memory -- it loads what it thinks you will need. The more space it has to do this the more likely it is to respond right away to your next request. Depending on what you do often and your storage space, entire applications might be preloaded. At the very least there could be enough loaded for the hard drive to finish seeking to the rest, meaning a faster response.

If this were just about swap I'd agree with you, but it's not intended primarily to hold a swap file. A couple gigabytes of memory is enough for almost anyone. If you really need more, then you really need more, and nothing else will do. On the other hand once you start trying to anticipate and prepare for what you will need other forms of storage, such as flash memory, start to look attractive based on their lower cost, non-volatility, and speed compared to a hard drive (50 s access time on a PCIe bus).

[quote]Quote:[hr]That shell thing can't be superior to the almighty Bash shell for UNIX systems! Remember that MS batch files language is very limited in comparison to Csh, Bash, and other *sh, scripting languages. If you don't know what I'm talking about, then you probably don't know Linux as well as I do. (Note that I'm (or I was???) still a Linux beginner.)[hr][/quote]
I live in the shell. Try doing some bash scripting then look into PowerShell and you'll never want to write something like the following (real code) again:
[pre] find $( echo $MANPATH | tr ":" " " ) -type f 2> /dev/null | grep -o "[^/]*$" | sed -e 's/\.[[:alnum:]]*\.gz/\ /g' | sort -u[/pre]
PowerShell is object oriented and provides hooks into the low-level parts of the system, meaning that awk and sed don't have to be your most used tools, and code can actually be readable more than a few hours after you write it.

Aero doesn't actually excite me much after having played with Beryl/Xgl. The power of OpenGL coupled with the traditional excellence of Linux's window managers is an unbeatable combination. The things I am excited about are SuperFetch (as described above), PowerShell, and the long-overdue UAC, in that order. UAC is mostly exciting because the majority OS is finally getting a semblance of decent security, not for its own merits, but the other two are genuinely new and exciting technologies. I also like the sound of the new driver model.________________

title: Re: Your Keen-o-matics
content:
Oops, I meant to add some newbie hints for Linux to the end of that last post, but since it's so long already I'll start another.

Ubuntu is a good distro to start with. Most distros would be all right but I see it as the "safe" newbie choice just because it's so common. Arch (mentioned above somewhere) is a great distro, but you'll have to install all the software you want explicitly from the command-prompt package manager. This is no hardship if you know exactly what you want, but if you're new it might be better to start with a more "bloated" distro that will give you more software to play with by default so you can get a feel for the landscape.

I also caught a question about interfaces compared to Windows. That's a pretty hard one to answer since there are so many choices. Most basic is the command line, and there are even three good options for this (although bash is certain to be the default). All of them are better than the Windows command line. Almost any distro (except for Arch Linux [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-crazy.gif[/img] ) includes some sort of desktop environment. Usually KDE or Gnome, but sometimes XFCE. All of these are better than the Windows desktop. GUI based configuration is somewhat lacking in comparison, not that I personally mind editing config files. An advanced user might want to forego the big desktops and just use a window manager with terminals to get everything done. This is my preferred way to work.

You'll probably be doing a lot of experimenting before you find your favorite way to do things. Have fun and ask questions!________________
